9.author: EntertainerFeeling94
9.body:
If you're wondering if it's even possible, yes. I've downloaded from FileJoker with the free option before, and it is possible.

It took me about 24\~ hours to download a 4.6 GB file. I don't recommend it: my downloads cut out a few times. I found the same thing hosted on FileJoker hosted on rutracker, only start downloading from FileJoker if you're extremely desperate, and if it's your last option.

My advice is to use something like a free vpn browser extension to have multiple downloads running at the same time. Not sure about your captcha problem - maybe an adblocker? You're absolutely sure you've selected all circles or shapes it asks you to?

Also, JDownloader is a download manager - separate from your casual internet browser.

15.body:
Okay I'm dumb and fatigued from being an idiot spending so long looking for a book that's not even vital, want to throw phone at wall!!.

I have tried the tor versions which return nothing, but I havnt tried brave or potentially the links you have above, if tor didn't have it are any of them worth trying?

15.author: TheWorldIsNotOkay
15.body:
I don't know what the IP addresses of the public websites were, or whether they're still active.  From what I can tell, it seems like the "main" versions of the site (with the .com or .org top-level domains) were basically mirrors hosted on virtual hosts provided by US companies (which is how the US government had the authority to seize those domains).  The IP addresses of those former domains therefore won't work.  I don't know of any other working public versions of ZLib in order to check their IP addresses.

And you can't access a web site hosted within the Tor network using an IP address, since Tor is specifically designed to prevent identifying a user's location by their IP address.  But using Tor is as easy as not using Tor (since the Tor Browser is just a modified version of Firefox, and the "New private window with Tor" option in Brave is a built-in variant of private browsing in a fork of Chrome), so the best thing for ZLib's continued existence is for people to use the version of the site Zlib is providing via the means they're providing it.

15.author: TheWorldIsNotOkay
15.body:
> I have tried the tor versions which return nothing, but I havnt tried brave or potentially the links you have above, if tor didn't have it are any of them worth trying?

I'm not really following what you're saying here.  The .onion links I provided are currently the only way to access Zlib.  You have to be using the Tor network to use a .onion link, and the easiest ways to use the Tor network are by using the Tor Browser or the "New private window with Tor" option in the Brave browser.    

You say you "have tried the tor versions" but then you say you haven't used the .onion links.  That's like saying you've looked for a product on Amazon but never used an electronic device.  The thing you said you didn't do is the way to do the thing you said you did do.

If you're saying you used the Tor Browser to access ZLib using one of the .onion links and weren't able to find anything, but haven't tried using the Brave browser, then you're out of luck.  The difference between using the Tor Browser and using the Brave browser is literally the difference between accessing a website using Firefox or Chrome.  It's still the same location, you're just using a different vehicle to get there.

15.author: Odd_Bodybuilder_2601
15.body: Ah yup I understand, I didn't know there was no diff between onion and tor, not used to using them

15.author: TheWorldIsNotOkay
15.body: Gotcha.  Just fyi, the top-level domain for those links is ".onion" because Tor was originally an acronym for "The Onion Routing network", so named because of the many layers of protection it provided to its users.  They've since dropped the acronym so that it's just "Tor", but the onion links stuck.

19.author: Dear_Evan_Hansen
19.body:
Pretty much safe to assume that if they have software on there to monitor you. They probably can log your keystrokes even. 

We’ve even been told at my company “use your work computers for personal use” but come on… they can see everything. 

What you should be afraid of, is if you make ripples big enough for them to care to look into it. Then they’ll dig in and find what they need.

19.author: kodak1999
19.body: keystrokes? actually just to make it clear, it is my personal laptop but I use company wifi, but you have my full curiosity and attention, they can actually monitor key strokes??

19.author: Dear_Evan_Hansen
19.body:
TL;DR - if there’s a way for your job to monitor your activity. Assume they can do it down to the keystroke, and that it gets saved/logged.

I said that it’s safe to assume that. Maybe I should’ve said “best” I don’t know for sure what my company monitors. I work from home so my situation is flipped from yours. Company laptop, personal internet. connect to a work VPN to develop/work on work shit.

About 3-4 times a day I get a live notification that my devices location has been accessed by <certain software> that we use. I have no idea what that notification is *really* checking. I assume it’s a snapshot type feature but anyway, the point is I don’t know for sure.

But then you hear stories of ppl getting fired because the company grabbed the webcam recordings (that they are legally allowed to access, because you likely signed that away right when you signed a contract to work from home/allow monitoring software) and they see that the employee was not working when they said they were. 

The important note here is, they were only motivated to access those recordings, because the employee did something stupid that motivated their IT department(or likely someone higher) to check in and see what the fuck happened.

This is a long way of saying. Assume everything you do on your computer is being logged and *can* be accessed *if necessary*

22.author: TheWorldIsNotOkay
22.body: The KFX plugin is for converting from the KFX format to some other format.  That can be done as part of the transfer if you choose to do so, or can be done separately.  Personally, I generally convert everything to EPUB since it's an open standard and slightly less likely to retain any social watermarking.  (Depending on how such watermarking might be done -- assuming it's even present at all -- this won't necessarily remove it, but I figure the further I can get the file from the original Amazon version the better off I'll be.)  When I add books back to the Kindle, Calibre automatically converts the books to MOBI, since my Kindle can't handle EPUBs.

22.author: FireTrail846
22.body: Alright, thanks for the info. But what do you mean your Kindle can't handle .epub files? My Kindle 6th gen can read epub files properly.

22.author: TheWorldIsNotOkay
22.body: No Amazon Kindle supports the EPUB format natively.  Amazon announced back in May 2022 that Kindles would support EPUBs by the end of the year, but what actually happened is that as of some time in December 2022 the "Send to Kindle" feature started allowing you to send EPUB files to your Kindle, but those EPUB files are quietly converted to AZW3 format rather than simply being transferred to the Kindle as EPUB files.

24.author: Rentlar
24.body:
Tough because Torrents stopped working 0kB/s is a symptom that could a huge variety of causes. We'd need more info if you wanted someone to dig in and provide better insight.

* Who's your ISP, are they known for throttling?
* Does Qbit show as connected? (green plug instead of red plug or orange flame?)
* Does a different or popular torrent work? Linux Isos are pretty reliably seeded you can test with.
* Did Windows update overnight or did the power go out at some point?
* Is the tracker working?

32.body:
I actually had a brand new V2 that I got for free on a credit card thing and I knew I couldn't afford the expensive games so I set on an adventure to find someone to trade my V2 for their V1.

I found an amazing guy on Marketplace that was selling his V2 the he also won in the credit card thing but in the description he said he had an old V1 he could sell too and somehow it was in perfect condition literally, the glass didn't have a single scratch and it had the original box with every accessory.

So that's how I got a free V1, I did this last month and now I have it with more than 30 games and it's amazing

32.author: Praline-Jumpy
32.body:
Oh really??
... still too much. Arrrh!

32.author: Praline-Jumpy
32.body: Oh,I didn't know that 2nd option is free...!

32.author: Praline-Jumpy
32.body: Maybe $1.20 per year/forever is what I'm willing to pay, but anything more then that is too much for me.
